message_1:
A substitution cipher replaces each letter in a message with a different letter of the alphabet. Suppose that a message encrypted using a substitution cipher has a frequency distribution of letters that looks like this:

| Letter | Frequency |
|--------|-----------|
| A      | 0.08      |
| B      | 0.05      |
| C      | 0.12      |
| D      | 0.05      |
| E      | 0.20      |
| F      | 0.08      |
| G      | 0.02      |
| H      | 0.04      |
| I      | 0.05      |
| J      | 0.00      |
| K      | 0.02      |
| L      | 0.05      |
| M      | 0.12      |
| N      | 0.05      |
| O      | 0.08      |
| P      | 0.02      |
| Q      | 0.00      |
| R      | 0.02      |
| S      | 0.05      |
| T      | 0.05      |
| U      | 0.02      |
| V      | 0.00      |
| W      | 0.02      |
| X      | 0.00      |
| Y      | 0.00      |
| Z      | 0.00      |

Assuming that the plaintext message is in English and that the most common letter in English is E (which has a frequency of approximately 0.127), which letter(s) in the frequency distribution are likely to correspond to E in the plaintext message?
message_2: In the given frequency distribution, the letter with the highest frequency is E with a frequency of 0.20. Since E is the most common letter in English with a frequency of approximately 0.127, it is likely that the letter E in the encrypted message corresponds to the letter E in the plaintext message.
